Arlo.Action: Pulls twice as many fish out of the water as Mason despite using the same equipment.
Defends Mason by denying knowing him and tries to defuse tension with humor.
Uses coarse language and insults Mason alongside him.
Calmly denies knowing Mason and avoids escalating the confrontation.
Advises to lighten up when confronted by authority, showing social awareness and emotional intelligence.
Engages in informal, somewhat disrespectful banter with Mason, which could undermine authority or escalate tension.
Offers Mason a 10% discount on the cash owed despite the inconvenience.
Insists on cash payment and interrupts Mason's attempt to offer a check, showing inflexibility.
Clearly states the amount owed and insists on cash payment as per new policy, showing awareness of financial details and policy changes.
Offers a 10% discount to resolve the cash collection issue amicably, demonstrating negotiation skills and practical problem-solving.
Interrupts Mason and insists on cash despite alternative payment options, which could be seen as inflexible or overly rigid.
Acknowledges that Andy did not call first and that would have been smart and fair, showing some critical thinking about process and communication.
Uses humor and sarcasm in conversation with Mason, which may undermine the seriousness of the situation and reduce perceived professionalism.
Offers to cover part of a payment and promises to make up the balance next month.
Insists others use his old truck despite many newer trucks being available.
Offers to pay $275 and negotiate terms to cover the balance next month.
Questions the need to use his old truck when there are many new trucks available.
Reluctantly accepts the situation and sighs without taking further initiative.
Suggests increasing the price to a hundred and fifty dollars to settle the matter.
Whispers to others to 'be cool' in a tense situation.
Offers to keep an eye out for the missing scientist.
Warns Mason not to be confrontational with a uniformed person.
Refuses to lend his truck, implying the need for another vehicle and more resources.
Whispers to others to stay calm and be cool in a tense situation.
Offers to keep an eye out for the missing scientist, showing awareness and willingness to help.
Advises Mason not to speak out aggressively to a uniformed person, demonstrating social awareness and tact.
Refuses Mason's request for his truck, suggesting Mason needs someone else's truck and a lot of ice, indicating strategic thinking.
Refuses to help Mason despite Mason's plea and offers of money, prioritizing his own interests and safety.
Dismisses Mason's belief in the dead man and the danger involved, mocking Mason's commitment.
Refuses to help Mason despite the urgency, prioritizing his own interests and showing reluctance to engage in a risky situation.
Clearly assesses the situation with the ice cream and the truck's condition, showing awareness of practical constraints and consequences.
Dismisses Mason's concerns and the danger involved, labeling others as 'wackos' without engaging with the problem, indicating a lack of constructive problem-solving.
Gives ice cream to the dog to keep him calm.
Argues aggressively and threatens Mason repeatedly.
Refuses to give up his truck despite pressure, shows protective attitude toward his property.
Expresses frustration and impatience but attempts to keep control of the situation.
Acknowledges mechanical issue with the truck (diesel injections flooded), indicating some technical knowledge.
Engages in overlapping arguments and threats rather than calm negotiation.
Argues persistently with Mason about the route, showing stubbornness and unwillingness to compromise.
Admits to borrowing the truck (though denies stealing), showing some honesty about his actions.
Argues about the route to McGruder, showing some local knowledge and insistence on avoiding Missoula.
Admits to having 'borrowed' the truck, which Mason interprets as stealing, indicating poor judgment or dishonesty.
Insists he did not steal the truck and explains the situation calmly.
Shows concern for old Pete's health by refusing to push him in the heat.
Insists he didn't steal the truck and asserts control over the route, showing confidence in decision-making.
Recognizes that old Pete can't handle the heat and suggests not pushing him, demonstrating awareness and practical judgment.
Engages in banter and laughter during a tense moment, which could indicate confidence or composure under pressure.
Panting and whispering 'Okay...' after a stressful event, possibly showing strain or difficulty coping.
Whispers 'Oh, shit' multiple times, showing surprise or fear rather than control.
Commands 'Get him to stand up, Night Shift.' showing some leadership and decisiveness.
Says 'Okay! All right!' indicating some attempt to take charge or encourage action.
Engages in hostile and insulting banter with Mason, calling him names and expressing aggression.
Claims to be a peaceful man who believes in live and let live.
Responds quickly and critically to Mason's comments, showing alertness and engagement in a tense situation.
Acknowledges the ongoing threat (vanload coming) and refuses to be complacent despite Mason's praise.
Uses sarcasm and insults in a stressful moment, which may undermine teamwork and communication.
Fails to de-escalate tension with Mason, escalating conflict instead.
Shows awareness of the situation's danger and maintains focus on the threat rather than celebrating prematurely.
Interrupts Mason to answer the phone and engages in a tense negotiation, showing protectiveness over his ice cream products.
Calls the antagonist a 'shithead' and firmly refuses to give up the package, showing loyalty and sincerity to his cause.
Interrupts tense phone call to assertively negotiate and protect his ice cream cargo, showing awareness of stakes and practical concerns.
Engages in a heated exchange with a threatening antagonist over the phone, maintaining composure and pushing back.
Expresses panic and fear (panting, 'Oh, shit', 'Oh, my God') during a tense situation.
Encourages and motivates 'old Pete' to keep going during a tense moment.
Expresses concern about the danger and the consequences for everyone involved.
Encourages and motivates 'old Pete' to start the vehicle under pressure.
Recognizes the danger of the situation, calculating the size and weight of the truck and the risk involved.
Expresses panic and doubt about their chances of success, highlighting the severity of the situation.
Repeatedly panics, expresses frustration and desperation, fails to take decisive or skillful action.
Attempts to encourage or motivate (himself or others) under stress, keeps trying despite difficulty.
Encourages Mason repeatedly to try and take action, showing persistence and confidence.
Expresses frustration and confusion during a difficult driving situation, indicating some lack of control or skill.
Continues to push forward despite physical strain and difficulty, showing determination and resilience.
Crying out in distress for Pete, showing emotional vulnerability.
Reassures with 'It's okay. Okay.' despite the tense situation.
Urgently tries to communicate and de-escalate with the driver: 'Listen! Listen... to him! You don't know who...'
Shows signs of distress and panic repeatedly (crying, saying 'Oh, shit!'), struggles physically (grunting, panting), but continues to push forward.
Attempts to communicate and intervene ('Listen! Listen... to him! You don't know who...'), indicating some situational awareness and effort to influence outcome.
Refuses to get in the dangerous vehicle, expressing concern for safety.
Encourages Mason despite fear and danger, ultimately follows him.
Refuses to get into the dangerous vehicle and expresses clear concern about the risk.
Eventually gives in and participates despite fear and hesitation.
Shows panic and whimpering under pressure, indicating emotional overwhelm.
Laughs and shares excitement with Mason during physical exertion and playful moments.
Expresses concern and surprise about the boat and ice cream situation, showing engagement and cooperation.
Asks Mason if he locked the truck, indirectly warning him about a potential problem.
Recognizes the temperature change in the river and comments on the ice cream not working, showing awareness of environmental conditions.
Suggests trying the river water despite the temperature concern, demonstrating willingness to experiment and adapt.
Asks Mason if he locked the truck, indicating attention to practical details and security.
Repeatedly yells and panics with exclamations like 'Oh, shit!' and 'Oh, no!'
Expresses frustration about being overlooked and treated unfairly despite hard work and loyalty.
Admits to taking the truck after feeling betrayed and ignored.
Admits to taking the truck after feeling unfairly treated and overlooked for promotions despite hard work and qualifications.
Expresses frustration and resentment about being passed over for opportunities due to nepotism and personal debts.
Responds to Mason's story with understanding and a bit of encouragement ('Well, shit. Could be worse... at least we have a paddle')
Remembers details about Robert Del Rio and connects with Mason's story, showing attentiveness and knowledge.
Responds to Mason's story with a somewhat dismissive or sarcastic comment ('Well, shit. Could be worse...'), which may indicate a lack of emotional intelligence or tact in the situation.
Reassures Mason that he didn't fully drag him into trouble, showing understanding and partial forgiveness.
Expresses commitment to finishing the task together with Mason, indicating loyalty and solidarity.
Shows awareness of the situation's stakes and expresses determination to finish the task despite risks.
Acknowledges limitations in others' abilities (Mason not a shooter) and assesses the real threat (Long).
Dismisses the idea of splitting early, indicating confidence in his own understanding and resolve.
Engages in lighthearted banter and enthusiasm (e.g., 'Whoo!'), showing confidence but not necessarily skill.
Sighs and says 'Damn' in moments of pause, possibly indicating frustration or uncertainty.
Takes Andy's truck without permission and mocks him about it.
Refuses to argue with Andy and shows a dismissive attitude.
Sarcastically suggests Andy get someone else to help him.
Keeps calm and responds to Andy's anger without escalating the situation.
Provides information about the truck's location when asked.
Uses humor and sarcasm in a tense situation, showing confidence.
Does not directly resolve the conflict or take clear action to fix the problem with Andy's truck.
Refuses to take the money, accusing Brynner of intending to kill them anyway.
Asks Mason if he is all right after a struggle.
Refuses to take the money, asserting it would have led to their death anyway.
Asks Mason if he is all right, showing awareness and concern in a tense situation.
Attempts to speak up or get attention by saying 'Hey!'
Expresses fear openly by repeatedly saying 'We're gonna die!'
Responds with hesitation and discomfort to Mason's odd request, but ultimately complies.
Pants heavily, repeatedly says 'We're gonna die!' and expresses panic instead of taking control or calming down.
Reluctantly follows Mason's instruction to reach into his pocket despite panic.
Repeatedly pants and grunts, showing physical exertion but no clear decisive or skillful action.
Says 'Okay, here we go' and 'Come on, come on!' indicating readiness and attempt to motivate or take initiative.
Apologizes for being a little (indistinct), possibly showing self-awareness but also uncertainty or hesitation.
Responds quickly to Mason's information about having Elvis, showing alertness and engagement.
Is panting and out of breath repeatedly, indicating physical strain or stress.
Does not take visible initiative or make strategic decisions in the excerpt, mostly reacting to Mason.
Identifies a nearby service station with ice to solve the immediate problem.
Expresses surprise or concern with 'Oh, shit.' after Mason's announcement.
Alerts team about approaching enemies and tunnel, showing situational awareness and communication.
Grunts in reaction to attack but no clear indication of effective counteraction or leadership.
Laughs and cheers with Mason, showing camaraderie.
Uses harsh language and insults (e.g., 'Unbe-fucking-lievable', 'Stupid') during a tense situation.
Explains the danger clearly and tries to communicate urgency to others.
Responds quickly and assertively to Mason's urging to floor the truck, showing awareness and confidence in a tense situation.
Clearly explains the danger of carrying a bomb in the tunnel, demonstrating understanding of the situation and ability to communicate urgency.
Expresses frustration and disbelief with exclamations like 'Unbe-fucking-lievable' and 'Stupid,' which may indicate emotional reaction rather than calm, calculated behavior.
Tries to mediate by suggesting to talk to the 'sage of Jerome' and identifies Vitelli as the Army contact, attempting to help the group communicate and survive.
Responds to tense situation with a resigned 'Shoot me' comment, showing some frustration but no hostility.
Identifies Vitelli as the key contact and tries to communicate this to others, showing awareness of the situation and relevant authority.
Responds with 'Shoot me' and provides a precise temperature reading under pressure, indicating calmness and attention to detail.
Communicates clearly over the telephone about the situation ('We've got Elvis on ice!') showing situational awareness and attempts to coordinate.
Expresses frustration and exhaustion ('We're too late.', panting) indicating possible stress but continues to engage actively.
Attempts to coordinate escape by asking Vitelli if they can get out on his end of the tunnel, showing presence of mind under pressure.
Speech is often indistinct and overlapping with others, which may indicate communication difficulties or lack of clarity.
Communicates clearly over the telephone about the dangerous smoke situation.
Asks Mason to hold something and continues panting, showing physical strain but still managing tasks.
Does not propose alternative escape routes or solutions despite the dangerous situation.
Encourages and helps others in the tunnel, addressing a woman as 'darlin'' and urging a big man to keep going.
Encourages and assists others in the tunnel, showing leadership and physical capability under stress.
Responds promptly and confidently to Mason's instructions, demonstrating situational awareness and teamwork.
Encourages Mason by calling them heroes and telling him to stop limping around negatively.
Boasts about their heroism and says 'We're the shit. Bigtime.'
Encourages Mason to act like heroes after saving many people, showing confidence and morale boosting.
Thanks Vitelli for the praise, showing awareness and acceptance of recognition.
Dismisses Mason's injury and negativity, showing some insensitivity and lack of empathy.
Engages in lighthearted banter and self-praise, which may indicate overconfidence or lack of seriousness.
Uses grunts and pants frequently without clear verbal communication in tense moments, indicating limited verbal leadership or clarity.
Acknowledges his courage and selfless actions that saved millions of lives.
Jokes about feeling owed restitution from the government after his service.
Engages in banter and negotiation despite threats, showing a somewhat lighthearted and resilient attitude.
Successfully negotiates with a threatening Army officer to save Mason and others, demonstrating courage and tactical skill.
Claims to be negotiating despite the threat of violence, showing confidence and quick thinking under pressure.
Acknowledges being jobless and truckless but still asserts entitlement to restitution, showing self-awareness and assertiveness.
Dismisses Mason's criticism of his negotiation tactics as 'bullshit,' showing some stubbornness and possible lack of humility.
Engages playfully with female medics, responds to their attention with lightheartedness.
Jokes about the mission and his undercover role, sharing a humorous story with Mason.
Claims to have saved many lives and speaks confidently about the mission.
Feigns fainting in a somewhat theatrical manner.
Makes a joke about being undercover as a tennis player with a code name and coach, showing humor but not serious competence.
Encourages a female medic to not be afraid and compliments her grip and walkie-talkie sincerely.
Encourages and instructs someone to have a strong grip and not be afraid, showing confidence and guidance.
Makes a lighthearted comment about a walkie-talkie, indicating awareness and social ease.
Describes his past role as carrying balls while Mason handled rackets, implying a less central or skilled role.
